metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.

content.text: React Getting Started
To use React in production, you need npm which is included with Node.js .
content.html: To use React in production, you need npm which is included with Node.js.

content.text: To get an overview of what React is, you can write React code directly in HTML.
content.html: To get an overview of what React is, you can write React code directly in HTML.

content.text: But in order to use React in production, you need npm and Node.js installed.
content.html: But in order to use React in production, you need npm and Node.js installed.

content.text: React Directly in HTML
The quickest way start learning React is to write React directly in your HTML files.
content.html: The quickest way start learning React is to write React directly in your HTML files.

content.text: W3Schools Spaces
The easiest way to get started with creating HTML files is W3Schools Spaces!
content.html: The easiest way to get started with creating HTML files is W3Schools Spaces!

content.text: It is the perfect place to create, edit, and share your work with others!
content.html: It is the perfect place to create, edit, and share your work with others!

content.text: Get started for free ❯
content.html: Get started for free ❯

content.text: Start by including three scripts, the first two let us write React code in our JavaScripts, and the third, Babel, allows us to write JSX syntax and ES6 in older browsers.
content.html: Start by including three scripts, the first two let us write React code in our JavaScripts, and the third, Babel, allows us to write JSX syntax and ES6 in older browsers.

content.text: You will learn more about JSX in the React JSX chapter.
content.html: You will learn more about JSX in the React JSX chapter.

content.code_html:
<!DOCTYPE html>
<html>
  <head>
    <script src="https://unpkg.com/react@18/umd/react.development.js" crossorigin></script>
    <script src="https://unpkg.com/react-dom@18/umd/react-dom.development.js" crossorigin></script>
    <script src="https://unpkg.com/@babel/standalone/babel.min.js"></script>
  </head>
  <body>

    <div id="mydiv"></div>

    <script type="text/babel">
      function Hello() {
        return <h1>Hello World!</h1>;
      }

      const container = document.getElementById('mydiv');
      const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(container);
      root.render(<Hello />)
    </script>

  </body>
</html>

content.text: This way of using React can be OK for testing purposes, but for production you will need to set up a React environment .
content.html: This way of using React can be OK for testing purposes, but for production you will need to set up a React environment.

content.text: Setting up a React Environment
If you have npx and Node.js installed, you can create a React application by using create-react-app .
content.html: If you have npx and Node.js installed, you can create a React application by using create-react-app.

content.text: If you've previously installed create-react-app globally, it is recommended that you uninstall the package to ensure npx always uses the latest version of create-react-app .
content.html: If you've previously installed create-react-app globally, it is recommended that you uninstall the package to ensure npx always uses the latest version of create-react-app.

content.text: To uninstall, run this command: npm uninstall -g create-react-app .
content.html: To uninstall, run this command: npm uninstall -g create-react-app.

content.text: Run this command to create a React application named my-react-app :
content.html: Run this command to create a React application named my-react-app:

content.code_html: npx create-react-app my-react-app

content.text: The create-react-app will set up everything you need to run a React application.
content.html: The create-react-app will set up everything you need to run a React application.

content.text: Run the React Application
Now you are ready to run your first real React application!
content.html: Now you are ready to run your first real React application!

content.text: Run this command to move to the my-react-app directory:
content.html: Run this command to move to the my-react-app directory:

content.text: Run this command to run the React application my-react-app :
content.html: Run this command to run the React application my-react-app:

content.text: A new browser window will pop up with your newly created React App! If not, open your browser and type localhost:3000 in the address bar.
content.html: A new browser window will pop up with your newly created React App! If not, open your browser and type localhost:3000 in the address bar.

content.text: The result:
content.html: The result:

content.text: Modify the React Application
So far so good, but how do I change the content?
content.html: So far so good, but how do I change the content?

content.text: Look in the my-react-app directory, and you will find a src folder. Inside the src folder there is a file called App.js , open it and it will look like this:
content.html: Look in the my-react-app directory, and you will find a src folder. Inside the src folder there is a file called App.js, open it and it will look like this:

content.code_html:
import logo from './logo.svg';
import './App.css';

function App() {
  return (
    <div className="App">
      <header className="App-header">
        <img src={logo} className="App-logo" alt="logo" />
        <p>
          Edit <code>src/App.js</code> and save to reload.
        </p>
        <a
          className="App-link"
          href="https://reactjs.org"
          target="_blank"
          rel="noopener noreferrer"
        >
          Learn React
        </a>
      </header>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;

content.text: Try changing the HTML content and save the file.
content.html: Try changing the HTML content and save the file.

content.text: Notice that the changes are visible immediately after you save the file, you do not have to reload the browser!
content.html: Notice that the changes are visible immediately after you save the file, you do not have to reload the browser!

content.code_html:
function App() {
  return (
    <div className="App">
      <h1>Hello World!</h1>
    </div>
  );
}

export default App;

content.text: Notice that we have removed the imports we do not need (logo.svg and App.css).
content.html: Notice that we have removed the imports we do not need (logo.svg and App.css).

content.text: The result:
content.html: The result:

content.text: What's Next?
Now you have a React Environment on your computer, and you are ready to learn more about React.
content.html: Now you have a React Environment on your computer, and you are ready to learn more about React.

content.text: In the rest of this tutorial we will use our "Show React" tool to explain the various aspects of React, and how they are displayed in the browser.
content.html: In the rest of this tutorial we will use our "Show React" tool to explain the various aspects of React, and how they are displayed in the browser.

content.text: If you want to follow the same steps on your computer, start by stripping down the src folder to only contain one file: index.js . You should also remove any unnecessary lines of code inside the index.js file to make them look like the example in the "Show React" tool below:
content.html: If you want to follow the same steps on your computer, start by stripping down the src folder to only contain one file: index.js. You should also remove any unnecessary lines of code inside the index.js file to make them look like the example in the "Show React" tool below:

content.code_html:
import React from 'react';
import ReactDOM from 'react-dom/client';

const myFirstElement = <h1>Hello React!</h1>

const root = ReactDOM.createRoot(document.getElementById('root'));
root.render(myFirstElement);
